author: joshd4078
content: Yes, you are welcome to add your updates to the repo. Also, make sure to add a link to the current weekly update thread (<#1130408928430276690> for this week) to make it easy for us and others to read and track your progress.

author: joshd4078
content:
Please remember, this program is meant to help your progress in your ability to do your own research and figure out the answers to problems on your own. None of the mentors are here to hold your hand through this process. **The first 3 weeks of the program is meant for your research and education **on the topics that you are interested in and not for reaching out to mentors about the projects they have listed.

Make sure that you are spending time looking at the resources available before asking for help.

author: angaz
content: Hi. I'm looking at the available ideas. One which I think is interesting is the total supply endpoint. This sounds like something I could work on. I would assume summing the total of every account would be an impossible task and would thrash the disk IO. So I'm thinking a running total calculated after each block would be better. It would need to be kept in the database so it can survive restarts. IDK exactly how the database works, can I put arbitrary keys there? The initial value would need to be calculated somehow and this could be a challenge without said disk thrashing. It could be calculated with a resync, but that doesn't sound very friendly to the node operators. Has someone done anything like this? Or any ideas that can send me down the right path?

author: joshd4078
content: <@&857649635274915900> There is no stand up meeting today. Our next call will be tomorrow's office hours.

author: royzhang
content: Hi there, I did look into this idea a bit. I think you maybe over think this idea.  The mint and burn is much easier to track. (take a reference on https://etherscan.io/stat/supply). It's unnecessary to track each EOA. I can imagine you can get all information you may need from block level.

author: wzht
content:
Cheers. Josh's message below your reply (here: https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/843176491386667018/1130453843608621116) also helped clarify the self-research aspect; I think that a discussion regarding the specific painpoints would count as research though no? As in I am not asking for "how do I do this?" but rather "what specific problems are you running into with the JSON-RPC API and how you consume it?".

That said the API surface looks smaller than I thought so getting it all done at once is probably much more feasible.
